metadata.case_name: Appellant v. State of West Bengal

facts.text: Gobinda Prasad Pandit, founder of Searsole Raj Estate, died in 1861 leaving a will.

After Gobinda Prasad Pandit's death, in a suit between his widow and other claimants, it was held that a charge was created upon the entire estate for maintenance and seva puja of family deity and specified charitable purposes.
In 1928, the appellant, his brother and their father executed an arpannamah in favour of the family deity reiterating the charge created by Gobinda Prasad Pandit.

On October 12, 1953, the appellant executed a document whereby a half share in a part of the estate was set apart exclusively for the purpose for which the charge had been created, and the rest of the property was treated as absolutely free from claims for religious and charitable purposes. Appellant appointed himself as trustee.
West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act, 1953 came into force on 12-2-1954; estate vested in State on 14-4-1955.
Act amended by introducing section 5A with retrospective effect from 5-5-1953.
Settlement Officer held the document of October 12, 1953 not bona fide after enquiry.
Petition to Calcutta High Court under Art. 227 dismissed on 23rd May, 1967 in Civil Rule No. 1119 of 1962.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court; appeal filed.
Total expenditure on seva and charitable purposes Rs. 30,000/-; appellant's share Rs. 15,000/-. Income of land absolutely transferred under 1953 deed Rs. 23,000/-.
Appellant transferred certain lands to his son and wife.

legal_issues.text: Whether the document executed by appellant on October 12, 1953 constitutes a 'transfer' under section 5A of the West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act, 1953.
Whether the transfer was not bona fide within the meaning of section 5A, i.e., made principally or partially to increase land retained or compensation payable.
Whether the facts raise a question under section 6(1)(i) of the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: No transfer at all as it was not an act of conveying property from one living person to another, and not a gift.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Definition of transfer; argued before Special Judge and High Court

respondent_arguments.text: Document is a transfer by way of gift as charitable trust is voluntary transfer; dedication to deity is transfer by gift under s.5A.
Transfer not bona fide as lands transferred to appellant's son and wife; done to defeat purpose of legislation.

court_reasoning.text: Document is a transfer; substance of endowing property to deity is a gift, even if not strictly under Transfer of Property Act definitions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cites Champa Bibi v. Panchiram Nahata AIR 1963 Cal 551 holding dedication to Hindu deity is transfer by gift under s.5A.

court_reasoning.text: Settlement Officer did not apply mind to s.5A criteria (increase land retained or compensation); merely repeated section words without reasons.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Facts show income of transferred land Rs.23,000 vs charge Rs.15,000; needed reasons how it increases retention/compensation.

court_reasoning.text: Special Judge erred in focusing on legal competence to free portion from charge and transfers to family, not on s.5A criteria.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court did not address s.5A question.

court_reasoning.text: No question under s.6(1)(i) as it relates to situation before 1953 document and unamended Act; earlier 1928 arpannamah and decree do not qualify per Fazlul Rabbi.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cites Fazlul Rabbi Pradhan v. State of West Bengal 1965 3 SCR 307.

holdings.text: Dedication of property to deity constitutes 'transfer' by gift under s.5A.
Lower authorities failed to properly determine if transfer not bona fide per s.5A criteria; matter requires fresh consideration.
No applicability of s.6(1)(i) to facts.

precedents_cited.relevance: Division Bench held transfer by dedication to Hindu deity is transfer by gift under s.5A(iii) of West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Fazlul Rabbi Pradhan v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Earlier documents like 1928 arpannamah and prior decree do not bring lands under s.6(1)(i).

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act, 1953
statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting of estates free from encumbrances; enquiry into non-bona fide transfers post 5-5-1953; retention of land for religious/charitable purposes; deductions for charitable payments; compensation calculation.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court directed to dispose of the matter afresh in accordance with law after proper consideration of s.5A criteria.
outcome.relief_granted: Remand to High Court for fresh disposal

key_quotes.text: "If the substance of the transaction by which properties are endowed in favour of a deity is looked into we do not see why it cannot be called a gift."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds 1953 document is a transfer by gift under s.5A.

key_quotes.text: "The Settlement Officer should, therefore, have given his reasons as to how he arrived at the conclusion that the transfer would enable the appellant to retain a larger extent of land or entitle him to a larger amount of compensation."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Criticizes lack of reasoned application of s.5A by lower authorities.
